title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.10 Part 3 | 17-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: This means that the Lord possesses transcendental qualities and therefore can attract everyone, including liberated souls.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the Atmarama verse and explains how even liberated souls are attracted to Krishna's transcendental qualities, mentioning examples like the four Kumaras, Shukadev Goswami, and the Gopis.
segments.transcript: In this session we will be discussing, continuing the discussion about the Atmarama verse, the 10th verse of the 7th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Just to refresh your memory, the Atmarama verse, which is the famous one, we have been discussing earlier two sessions. This is the third session, I am continuing the discussion on this verse. आत्मा रामाश्यमुनयो निर्ग्रन्था अप्युरुक्रमे कुर्वन्ति अहीतुकिं भक्तिं इत्थं भूत गुणो हरिही. The meaning of this is, all different varieties of Atmaramas, Atmaramas are those who take pleasure in Atma or the spirit self, especially those established on the path of self-realization, though freed from all kinds of material bondage, desire to render unalloyed devotional service unto the personality of Godhead. This means that the Lord possesses transcendental qualities and therefore can attract everyone, including liberated souls. So, we already discussed how different personalities were attracted to Krishna, even though they were situated, some of them were situated in the impersonal liberation. For example, the four Kumaras and Shukadev Goswami. And I also mentioned in the previous session how the Gopis were attracted to Krishna. Now, I am going to talk about the Gopis.

segments.key_quote: Krishna's qualities are so very attractive, because somebody possesses some nice qualities that is attractive, then when we come across such a person, we become attracted to that person.
segments.summary: The speaker continues discussing Krishna's all-attractive nature, quoting Chaitanya Mahaprabhu and highlighting how even the queens of Dwaraka and the goddess of fortune are drawn to Krishna's beauty and qualities.
segments.transcript: I am continuing the discussion about the other personalities attracted by Krishna. This is described by Chaitanya Mahaprabhu to Sanatana Goswami. So, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu says, The queens in Dwaraka, headed by Rukmini, are also attracted to Krishna simply by hearing about his transcendental beauty and qualities. Simply by hearing about his transcendental beauty and qualities. This Atmarama verse is all about Krishna having unlimited transcendental qualities, attributes by which he attracts everyone. That's why he is called all-attractive. Krishna means all-attractive. He attracts everybody without exception. So, here is a statement in the Bhagavatam that Chaitanya Mahaprabhu is quoting. O most beautiful Krishna, I have heard about your transcendental qualities from others, and therefore all my bodily miseries are relieved. If someone sees your transcendental beauty, his eyes have attained everything profitable in life. O infallible one, I have become shameless after hearing of your qualities, and I have become attracted to you. So, Krishna's qualities are so very attractive, because somebody possesses some nice qualities that is attractive, then when we come across such a person, we become attracted to that person. That's natural. But here, Krishna's attraction is so very powerful, that nobody else can possess qualities like Krishna to the extent that they may attract somebody more than Krishna. That is not possible. Further, Lord Chaitanya says, Lord Krishna attracts even the mind of the goddess of fortune

segments.key_quote: O Lord, we do not know how the serpent Kalia attained such an opportunity to be touched by the dust of your lotus feet.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Kalia being subdued by Krishna and the Nagapatnis' prayers, emphasizing the surprising fortune of Kalia to receive the dust of Krishna's lotus feet, a blessing even the goddess of fortune strives for.
segments.transcript: simply by vibrating his transcendental flute. There is a statement in the Bhagavatam by the Nagapatnis. O Lord, we do not know how the serpent Kalia attained such an opportunity to be touched by the dust of your lotus feet. Kalia was chastised by Krishna. And because Kalia's wives, the Nagapatnis, were devotees of Krishna, Krishna spared the life of Kalia. Because the Nagapatnis otherwise would have become widowed. So, Krishna, on the request of the Nagapatnis, spared his life. But still, how did he get the dust of the lotus feet of Krishna on his head? What did Krishna do to subdue Kalia? He actually pounded Kalia's hoods. So, in the process, Kalia got the blessings of the dust of the lotus feet of Krishna. So, the Nagapatnis are expressing surprise. He is a very, he has a sinful background. That's how he took the body of a serpent with so much of venom in his body. And unnecessarily such venomous serpents bite others and kill them. Innocent people, innocent creatures. So, it's not a very good birth because of past sinful activities. In spite of that, in spite of possessing such a body, how did Kalia be fortunate enough to get the dust of the lotus feet of Krishna? That is what the Nagapatnis are expressing in their prayers to Krishna. They are telling to get the dust of the lotus feet of Krishna. The goddess of fortune performed austerities for centuries, giving up all of their desires and taking austere vows. Means it's not easy for someone to get the dust of the lotus feet of Krishna on their head. Indeed, we do not know how this serpent Kalia got such an opportunity, which even goddess of fortune, it is difficult to attain. How did Kalia get that? That is the surprise that the Nagapatnis express in their prayers to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: My dear Lord Krishna, where is that woman within the three worlds who would not be captivated by the rhythms of the sweet songs coming from your wonderful flute?
segments.summary: The speaker explains how Krishna attracts everyone in the three worlds, including young girls, cows, birds, and even trees, highlighting the different relationships people in Vrindavan have with Krishna (motherly, servant, friend, father).
segments.transcript: Next, Lord Chaitanya explains, Krishna attracts not only the minds of the gopis and the goddesses of fortune, but the minds of all the young girls in the three worlds as well. How is that? That is another statement in the Bhagavatam. My dear Lord Krishna, where is that woman within the three worlds who would not be captivated by the rhythms of the sweet songs coming from your wonderful flute? Who would not fall down from the past, though chastity in this way. Your beauty is the most sublime within the three worlds. Upon seeing your beauty, even cows, birds, animals and trees in the forest become stunned in jubilation. So, if such creatures like cows and birds can become captivated, what to speak of the girls in the three worlds, the women in the three worlds. So, the women of Vrindavan who are on the level of superior guardians are attracted to Lord Krishna maternally. That means as mother, in a motherly relationship. The men of Vrindavan are attracted as servants, friends and fathers. Mind you, this is the description that everyone is attracted by Krishna. Everyone. Therefore, the term Krishna all attractive applies only to the Supreme Personality of God, Krishna and nobody else. Further, it is described here. The qualities of Krishna captivate and attract everything, living and non-living. Even birds, animals and trees are attracted to Krishna's qualities. This is already mentioned in the previous verse.

segments.key_quote: One meaning is that the Lord who is called as Hari takes away all inauspicious things from his devotee.
segments.summary: The speaker begins to explain the meaning of the name 'Hari' in the context of the Atmarama verse, focusing on how Krishna removes inauspiciousness from devotees and steals their minds with ecstatic love.
segments.transcript: Now, coming to the word Hari. Although the word Hari has many different meanings, two of them are foremost. In connection with the usage of the word Hari in this verse, ittham bhuta guno hari hi. The Supreme Personality of Godhead who is also called Hari is full of so many nice qualities by which she attracts everyone. This is a reference to the verse in which the word Hari is used. Now, which sense the word Hari is used? One meaning is that the Lord who is called as Hari takes away all inauspicious things from his devotee. Hari means one who takes away, one who steals. So, what does Krishna take away that he is referred to as Hari? He takes away all inauspicious things from his devotees. Isn't it so nice? Of course, this doesn't refer to devotees who are already free from all bad qualities or all inauspiciousness. It refers to devotees who are on the path, just entering the path of pure devotional service and very quickly they become purified by coming in touch with the Supreme Lord Krishna. The second meaning of the word Hari in this context of its usage in this Atmarama verse is that he attracts the mind by ecstatic love for God. He steals away the mind of those devotees who are looking after love of Krishna and by giving them the love, reciprocating them with them in love. He attracts their mind. So, now the name Hari the way it is used in Atmarama verse Chaitanya Mahaprabhu explains When the devotee some or other always remembers the Supreme Personality of Godhead anywhere and everywhere Devotee means he always thinks of Krishna. Krishna says in Bhagavad Gita Devotees who are practiced always think of Krishna. Such devotees what happens? Lord Hari takes away life's four miserable conditions. What are the four miserable conditions?

segments.key_quote: Krishna says I will protect you from all sinful reactions Do not fear
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how Krishna, as Hari, takes away the four miserable conditions of life caused by sinful activities, explaining the gradations of sin and quoting the Bhagavad Gita to emphasize Krishna's promise to protect those who surrender, regardless of their past sins, listing illicit sex, intoxication, gambling, and meat-eating as the four basic sinful activities.
segments.transcript: of life in this material world? So, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport. The four miserable conditions are due to the four kinds of sinful activities known as 1. Pathaka 2. Urupathaka 3. Mahapathaka 4. Atipathaka. What do they mean? Pathaka means preliminary sin and Urupathaka means very great sin and Mahapathaka means greater sin and Atipathaka means the topmost sin. Among sinful activities there are gradations. So, based on the gradations there are four different gradations. Now doesn't matter whether somebody is committing sinful activities which are of lower grade or intermediate grade or very high grade. It doesn't matter. Krishna assures the devotee aham tvam sarva papebhya moksha itshyami mahashu jahan. That means if somebody surrenders to Krishna even if before surrendering he was very very sinful Krishna says I will protect you from all sinful reactions. Do not fear. This is the verse in the Bhagavad Gita aham tvam sarva papebhya moksha itshyami mahashu jahan. Now here Srila Prabhupada particularly explains the word sarva papebhya literally means all sinful reactions. Now here particularly Prabhupada is telling the word sarva papebhya indicates four kinds of sinful activities. Which are the four kinds? The four kinds of sinful activities which are classified as pataka, uru pataka, maha pataka and ati pataka. It doesn't matter how sinful a devotee had been before coming to Krishna consciousness Krishna takes away all the sinful reactions before, rather takes away the sinful reactions all kinds of sinful reactions when the devotee surrenders to Krishna. The four basic sinful activities Prabhupada is reminding us are summarized in the Bhagavad Gita as illicit sex, intoxication, gambling and meat eating. So Krishna takes away all the sinful reactions. So therefore he is called Hari. I will stop here.
